body:
@sophokles73 : With having PR #875 we now have a solution so that custom protocol adapters can reopen command receiver links themselves.
So I propose to remove this issue from the 0.8 project.

What remains a *fundamental* problem IMHO though are command receiver links for MQTT devices that stay connected for long.

Maybe the default implementation of the `connectionLost` handler in the MQTT adapter should close the MQTT connection (instead of inheriting the NOP implementation of the base class), or am I missing something?
This should be small work and could be done instead of fixing this issue in 0.8.

WDYT?

> Maybe the default implementation of the connectionLost handler in the MQTT adapter should close the MQTT connection (instead of inheriting the NOP implementation of the base class), or am I missing something?

That should do the trick, yes. In fact, only those connections to devices need to be closed, which have subscribed to the control topic. BTW the same holds true for the AMQP adapter.

If we implemented this default behavior in the MQTT and AMQP adapter, don't you think we could close this issue as fixed?

> In fact, only those connections to devices need to be closed, which have subscribed to the control topic. 

:+1: this is true.

> If we implemented this default behavior in the MQTT and AMQP adapter, don't you think we could close this issue as fixed?

Yes, after the MQTT and AMQP adapters are equipped with such a connection-loss handler, this issue can be closed IMHO.

issue.title: Handle command connection loss
issue.body:
This PR addresses #830 

A straightforward approach for solving the issue would be to simply re-create all links once the connection is re-restablished. However, with a large number of devices connected to the adapter instance, this might result in a *burst* of link establishment traffic whose outcome is hard to predict.

The approach taken by this PR is therefore a different one: when a device subscribes to commands and a corresponding CommandConsumer is created, a device specific liveness check is registered which periodically checks for the link to be *alive* and, if not, tries to re-create the link. This should provide for much better distribution of re-creation attempts while being able to automatically recover from the connection loss.
